Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Now a certain background for this verse is that the Srimad Bhagavatam
is the last work of Vyasa Deva. Vyasa Deva compiled the Vedic literature as we have it today.
Because before Vyasa Deva compiled the Vedic literature, what was available was only in the form of Shruti,
the Vedas were available as that which was heard and passed on through oral tradition.
Oral tradition means the Guru will speak, the disciple will hear and as soon as the disciple hears,
he will commit to memory. Just he hears once and he commits to memory and he is able to remember the rest of the verse.
And after hearing from the Guru and committing to memory, the disciple will try to understand
the meaning of what is heard from the Guru and then he will deliberate on the meaning
and ask questions from the Guru and try to understand and realize this subject matter
of the Vedas. This is called Shrutapantha. Understanding, learning, understanding and realizing through hearing.
Now in the beginning of Kali Yuga, Vyasa Deva appeared for a very specific reason.
He could see that in Kali Yuga, people's memory will be very short-lived.
Their lifespan also will be reduced.
In Kali Yuga, people's duration of life is shortened.
In Sakya Yuga, the duration of life was 100,000 years, 1 lakh years.
And that duration of life reduced in Treta Yuga, the next Yuga, to 10,000 years.
Further reduced in the next Yuga, called Dwapar Yuga, to 1,000 years.
And in Kali Yuga, the last of the four Yugas, in the cycle of four Yugas, the last Yuga, Kali Yuga,
it is further reduced to 100 years.
So the duration of life being reduced, the time available for studying the Vedas is also very less.
Not only that, people's memory has also become less.
In Kali Yuga, duration of life, memory and so many other such good qualities are reduced.
So Vyasa Deva foreseeing this condition of human beings in Kali Yuga,
he first of all decided to put the Vedas in writing.
So Vedas were put into writing at the end of Dwapar Yuga, just before the beginning of Kali Yuga, by Vyasa Deva.
The name Vyasa is actually a title.
It is a title which indicates that
one who records, one who puts down in writing and creates a record,
Actually, the Vyasa title is given to the incarnation of the Lord who appeared at the end of Dwapar Yuga,
His full name is Krishna Dwaipaayana Vyasa.
He is an incarnation of the Supreme Lord who has appeared for a very special purpose.
The first of the reasons is that he put down the Vedas in writing.
He put down the Vedas in writing.
